evidence: A ductile V 0.5 Nb 0.5 ZrTi refractory high-entropy alloy (RHEA) with relatively low density (~6 g/cm À 3 ) is investigated, designed by controlling its valence electron concentration. The homogenized alloy exhibits a stable BCC structure, significant work hardening rate and considerable tensile stress (787 MPa) and elongation (21.9%). The solid-solution strengthening effect is estimated to be ~575 MPa by simplifying into a pseudo-binary alloy, which is in accordance with the test results.

The as-cast alloy displays the yield stress of ~832 MPa, the ultimate tensile strength of ~913 MPa and the plastic elongation of ~18.6%. After homogenization, the stress decreases to ~787 MPa, but the elongation increases up to 21.9%. The density of V 0.5 Nb 0.5 ZrTi alloy is ~6.10 g/cm 3.

A novel V 0.5 Nb 0.5 ZrTi alloy is fabricated by vacuum arc melting successfully. This alloy exhibits a single BCC phase, which maintains a high structure stability up to1450 � C. The tensile yield stress, ultimate stress and true strain of homogenized alloy (1150 � C/24 h) are 787 MPa, 830 MPa and 21.9%, respectively.
